reviewText: About the movie--Antonio Margheriti's THE SQUEEZE (aka "Diamond Thieves") would be an adequate crime drama if it wasn't so darn dated. Here a mega-annoying homogenized disco music score, plus some polyester threads and a bizarrely shaped Afro all scream: "late 70s schlock!!!"Star Lee Van Cleef's long hair and bald pate make him look much older than his 53 years. Karen Black's 'nails on the blackboard' Bronx accent is spot-on, although her comic relief isn't. Edward Albert, son of GREEN ACRES star Eddie is good here, as are character actor Lionel Stander (BARETTA) and Robert Alda (father of Alan). Balance of the cast is European, best known being Ron Van Clief.Albert plays the son of a friend of ex-safecracker Van Cleef who convinces the older man to leave his Mexican horse ranch to pull one final high-paying jewel heist. Van Cleef learns that after he opens the safe, the Germans who've arranged this robbery will kill him and keep all the diamonds, so he double-crosses them never suspecting that his young friend has done the same to him.Van Cleef catches a bullet in the leg during his escape which is how he meets the slightly nutsy Black. This socially-conscious lone tenant of an abandoned apartment house removes the slug and bandages his wound. Stander is the pawnshop owner who plans to fence the stolen rocks and Alda is a NYC detective trying to solve the case. The real mystery here though is why this at times disjointed picture isn't better than it is. (2.5 stars out of 5)
summary: aka Der Diamantencoup, aka Controrapina, aka The Rip Off, aka L'ultimo colpo, aka...

reviewText: My praise for this film goes not to Van Cleef, but Karen Black for the remarkable way she maintained her accent through out her performance.  She`s alway a pleasure to watch especially in her rauchy roles.  Though she doesn`t appear until late in the film, she`s worth the wait. The sound and picture quality are pretty good for this budget movie.

reviewText: I love Lee Van Cleef.  What else can one say?  It's a cops and robbers of not very high priority but fun.Mr. Beady Eyes - but not unattractive.  And not a bad story.
Title: N/A

reviewText: (This is a review of THE SQUEEZE with Michael Keaton & Rae Dawn Chong, not a Lee Van Cleef film.)This sleeper surprised me. It's well-made & pretty funny, with a good cast & captures the crazy eighties pretty well, money-mad Reaganomics & all.Keaton is his usual insane self, a fast-talking avant-guarde artist/hustler working the New York club scene, in hock to his eyebrows to loan sharks, trying to bed process-server Chong & winds up getting involved in a huge Lotto scam. Meatloaf is a hilariously intense psychopath. The movie is typical of the era, outlandish & gaudy, but the script is funny & fast-moving. Keaton is great as usual & carries the film on chutzpah & moxie.It deserves to be on DVD, since it's at least as good as most of the DVDs out there. It would sell.
summary: Michael Keaton at his crazy best..
